News and developments from Justia and the tech world -----
March 2017
 

Welcome to the March 2017 edition of 
the Justia monthly newsletter!

Get an inside look at new developments in the online marketing world, keep up with the latest social media trends, and hear about what’s happening at the JUSTIA offices.

FEATURED NEWS

The Importance of High-Quality, Original, Focused Content

One of the best investments a law firm can make is in high-quality, original, focused content for their website. Content not only drives SEO, but it is also crucial for attracting and retaining readers, and for converting those readers into clients. Justia CEO Tim Stanley offers insights into writing high-quality content, and he discusses the importance of having that content also be both original (non-duplicative) and focused.


Tech News

Apple, Facebook, Google, Microsoft and 93 Other Tech Companies Call Travel Ban ‘Unlawful’ in Rare Coordinated Legal Action

In an unusual move, almost 100 of Silicon Valley’s leading tech businesses signed onto an amicus brief filed with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit, opposing the Trump administration’s controversial executive order banning immigration from seven majority-Muslim countries. In the filing, the companies stated that in addition to departing from principles of fairness, the executive order would harm their ability to attract talent and investment to the United States from around the world. Later that week, the 9th Circuit declined to stay the Washington district court order enjoining enforcement of the ban while the government appeals that decision.

For First Time, FTC Says TV Viewing Data Is Sensitive Data

In a groundbreaking settlement, smart TV maker Vizio has agreed to pay over $2.2 million following allegations by the FTC and the New Jersey attorney general’s office that it improperly collected and used consumer viewing data. Vizio was accused of deceiving consumers by collecting second-by-second information from 11 million internet-connected devices regarding their viewing habits without informed consent, and selling the data to third parties. This is a landmark outcome because it is the first time the FTC has designated TV viewing data as “sensitive information,” a category that carries special protection for consumers. It also signals a potential new era of oversight for TV data collection, an area that has seen little regulation in the past.

Homeland Security Secretary: Travel Vetting Could Include Passwords, Tweets

Recently confirmed Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly has stated that residents of the seven majority-Muslim countries targeted by Trump’s recent attempted immigration ban may be required to provide passwords and lists of websites visited before entering the U.S. Immigration officials are also considering reviewing applicants’ social media use, cell phone contacts, and financial information as a means of vetting that data against information the U.S. and E.U. already have on file.

Yahoo Hit With Data Breach Class Action Lawsuit Claiming Credit Card Details Stolen

Following disclosures of two separate hacks that together compromised an estimated 1.5 billion user accounts, Yahoo has been the target of at least two dozen lawsuits, the most recent being a data breach class action suit alleging that credit card data was stolen as a result of the breaches. Filed in federal court in San Jose, the lawsuit claims that the named plaintiff incurred fraudulent charges on two credit cards, and was later a victim of identity theft. He alleges that Yahoo’s conduct amounted to deceptive business practices, though Yahoo has previously stated that credit card data was not believed to be vulnerable as a result of the hacks.

Diehard Coders Just Rescued NASA’s Earth Science Data

Concerned about the preservation of government science data under the new presidential administration, coders across the country are beginning coordinated efforts to collect and save this data on non-government servers. Hackers, scientists, and students are working frantically to archive data legally retrieved from numerous government websites and databases, and to devise systems for tracking any changes to currently posted information. Areas of interest include data not only related to climate change, but other scientific, historical, and cultural issues.

SEO News

Unconfirmed Google Algorithm Update May Be Better at Discounting Links and Spam

SEO industry observers believe that an unconfirmed Google algorithm change took place at the beginning of February, and is targeting link spam as well as other types of spam. The update, which may have simply been a change to Google’s 2012 Penguin update, seems to be having a negative impact on sites with spammy links, or that employ “black hat” SEO tactics.

Google Fixes a Big Problem with AMP, Now Lets You View and Share a Publisher’s Own Links

In February, Google rolled out a change to its Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) integration in Google Search. AMP is a project by Google aimed at speeding up web browsing on mobile devices by offering optimized versions of publisher sites, free of third-party scripts and other mechanisms that may slow or stop a page from loading. This latest change makes it possible to view, copy, and share a publisher’s own web page links, rather than the AMP URLs.

The Single Best Anchor Text for SEO That No One Is Talking About

Not all anchor text is created equal. This article breaks down anchor text into twelve distinct categories, explains how each differs from one another, and makes a case for the most important type of anchor text for those interested in improving their website’s search term rankings.

2017’s Four Most Important Ranking Factors, According to SEO Industry Studies

There are hundreds of different factors that come into play when determining Google’s search rankings. Focusing on a few specific rankings factors can go a long way in helping to maximize your SEO strategy. From quality content to a selection of technical factors that should not be overlooked, here are four rankings components that are worth your time and effort to optimize.

Social Media News

Facebook Argues in Court It Can't Monitor All Posts for Racist Language

In an attempt to prevent an order from a German court that would force it to block a photo that has been misused in multiple hate-speech postings, Facebook attorneys have argued the social network can’t monitor all of its users’ posts for racist language. The suit arose when a Syrian refugee’s selfie with Chancellor Angela Merkel started being shared on Facebook with what the man claims are libelous statements added by other Facebook users.

How LinkedIn Markets on LinkedIn (Infographic)

Professional networking site LinkedIn recently conducted a study on marketing on its own platform and published its results in a helpful infographic. Among other things, the study showed that content that included a statistic received more clicks than content without, shorter posts received more engagement, and the use of multiple-layer campaigns (e.g., InMail and Sponsored Content together) resulted in higher click-through rates.

Twitter Plans to Hide Abusive Tweets, Block Repeat Offenders

After years of criticism that it hasn’t done enough to combat abuse on its platform, Twitter recently announced changes to its policy that would make abusive users less effective. With these changes, Twitter will hide the content of abusive users (rather than delete their content altogether) and prevent banned users from creating new accounts.

Twitter is Sending Some Users to the Penalty Box

In related news, Twitter is also reportedly temporarily limiting some users' accounts for "potentially abusive behavior." This indicates that the company is more responsive to the continued criticism that it does not do enough to curb abuse on its platform.

Legal Industry News

Most States Now Require Tech Competence for Lawyers. What Does That Mean For You?

Legal ethics rules in a majority of states now require attorneys to become and remain familiar with technologies that affect their practices. States across the country have begun to provide more specific guidance as to what these ethical duties entail, giving lawyers specific examples that may apply directly or analogously to the technologies they use every day.

Trump Immigration Order Affects Moot Court

While pundits and commentators knew that the effects of President Trump’s executive order restricting immigration to the United States would have far-reaching effects, one potentially unexpected consequence was on an international moot court competition. Two teams, one from Iran and one from Iraq, will almost surely not be able to attend the prestigious Jessup International Moot Court Competition in April due to the order.

Jury Awards Ousted General Counsel Nearly $8M; Metadata is Said to Be Important Evidence

A San Francisco jury awarded nearly $8 million to a whistleblower after he showed that a negative performance review was actually created after his firing date, as indicated by metadata associated with the performance review.

Justia Ask A Lawyer provides a platform for non-lawyers to post basic legal questions online and get free responses from attorneys. Sign up to receive an email in real time when a question is submitted in your practice area and locality, allowing you to be the first to answer a question and earn more points!

Internet Stats

Voice Searches - Query Breakdown

The growth of voice search has great potential to affect how local businesses are found. ComScore estimates that by 2020, a full 50 percent of all searches will be by voice.

POWERED BY JUSTIA

JurisPro® Expert Witness Directory

JurisPro provides a free directory of expert witnesses in over 10,000 areas of expertise.

Recent cases involving expert witness testimony:


Insurance Expert's Testimony Improperly Speculative

Although the court allowed insurance expert to testify on the handling of an underinsured motorist claim, speculative comments using words such as "may" or "possibly" were excluded.


Electrical Engineer Should Have been Excluded Under Daubert

The U.S. Court of Appeals found the District Court committed reversible error in failing to test expert's theories under the Daubert Standard.


Police Procedures Testifies on Excessive Force Against An Emotionally Disturbed Person

The court allowed a police procedures expert to testify in a case involving the fatal shooting of an emotionally disturbed person who allegedly yielded a knife at the police.
